The Canadian Coast Guard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian Pacific Railway paid homage to a true Canadian hero with the unveiling of a commemorative plaque aboard the Canadian Coast Guard Ship Private Robertson V.C. in Burlington Ontario December 10 2017.

Private James Peter Robertson was awarded posthumously the Victoria Cross for his extraordinary valour and devotion to duty while facing a hostile force in one of the most significant battles in World War I, at Passchendaele Belgium.

CP commissioned the plaque at the request of CP engineer Darrel Sundholm of Calgary Alberta. “After his family moved from Springhill Nova Scotia to Medicine Hat Alberta, James Peter Robertson joined the Canadian Pacific Railway, working his way up to locomotive engineer. He earned his nickname “Singing Pete” for his cheerful singing and whistling, whether in the cab or at the roundhouse,” said Sundholm. “The bravery that earned him the Victoria Cross made him a legend among locomotive engineers the world over.”

Steve Pauley, Commanding Officer of the Canadian Coast Guard ship named in Robertson's honour stated at the ceremony “In this, the 100th year anniversary of his death, it is our honour to share the story of Private Robertson’s service to our country and remember his ultimate sacrifice with dignity and respect.” Pauley added “This plaque will educate all who step aboard this ship for many years to come.”

In Newfoundland and Labrador the Canadian Coast Guard has 21 light stations with solar charging arrays and battery banks. Two of these stations have hybrid systems that use both wind and solar charging. The hybrid systems are located at Green Island in Fortune Bay and Puffin Island in Bonavista Bay.

A fully operational hybrid system, at a staffed light station, can save approximately 25,000 litres of fuel per year. By using the power of the sun and the wind, we can save from 4,000 to 8,000 litres of fuel annually at each site because fewer helicopter and vessel visits are required.

The Government of Canada is committed to a clean environment and reduced carbon pollution. By utilizing greener power sources, we can help reduce Canada’s carbon footprint.

After a mandatory safety briefing, on the ground in Iqaluit, #Arctic, Canadian Coast Guard Helicopter 442 , transported a second group of 11 students and two staff from the Nunavut Fisheries and Marine Training Consortium, #NFMTC, to ship from shore, to participate in a day at sea, aboard CCGS Henry Larsen in Frobisher Bay, on Friday, November 10.
 
Following a schedule similar to the one executed earlier in the week, all NFMTC participants were once again engaged by the proud crew in shipboard operations, hands-on training, introduction to engine room machinery and discussions about life on board the ship. This full day of training also included an opportunity for crew to share a meal with the eager students and staff. Of note, CCGS Henry Larsen’s 1ST Engineer Dan White not only eagerly explained the duties of an engine room officer on watch to the students but also celebrated 35 years of service with Coast Guard that very same day!
 
Captain Peter Richards, NFMTC, expressed in a note to Captain MacDonald afterwards, that the entire class was extremely pleased with the day onboard the ship. He said that the crew did a fantastic job showing the workings of the ship, were informative, engaging and very keen to share their knowledge and experiences. Citing this as an immense learning opportunity, Captain Richards feels this will give the students other career options when considering a future in the marine industry. Bravo Zulu CCGS Henry Larsen! #CCGProud!

Weeks of planning paid off for the Nunavut Fisheries and Marine Training Consortium, NFMTC, in Iqaluit and the Canadian Coast Guard. Starting with a visit to the NFMTC college by CCGS Henry Larsen’s Commanding Officer Neil MacDonald, it was followed up by two days of shipboard training and information sharing. 
 
On Wednesday, November 8th, the NFMTC Bridge Watch Rating class was enthusiastically welcomed aboard CCGS Henry Larsen by Captain MacDonald and his crew. A total of 14 students and staff were divided into three groups and sent to various work stations onboard the icebreaker. They learned about anchoring operations and how a windlass works. They were briefed on launching lifeboats during rescue operations; and about the safe operation of deck machinery including mooring and towing winches. As well, they learned how to steer a large vessel while underway as they pulled up the anchor and sailed in Frobisher Bay for a few hours. The enthusiastic and supportive crew were also able to describe shipboard life and share their experiences working with the Coast Guard. 
 
Captain Phil Hillier, NFMTC, noted that for many students, being on board a vessel of this size was a first for most and that being able not only see how the ship operates but also to actually have hands-on experience was very important in supplementing what is taught at the marine college. Captain Hillier was confident that this experience will motivate the students to want to further a career in the marine industry.

Lieutenant-Commander Dussault joined the Naval Reserve in 1993.  She started her reserve career as a Naval Control of Shipping (NCS) officer, participating in and planning NATO and domestic NCS exercises, and holding various divisional positions at HMCS RADISSON, HMCS DONNACONA, HMCS CARLETON and HMCS CATARAQUI. In 2003, she was appointed Deputy Commander of Naval Cooperation and Guidance for Shipping Unit 2, and then transferred in the same position for Unit 3 to thereafter take command of this unit under Maritime Operational Group 5 in 2007. Since, she re-trained as an Intelligence Officer, has held staff and academic positions at the Toronto Canadian Forces College, and has recently completed a term as Executive Officer of HMCS CARLETON.
 
In 2007-08 she deployed to Kabul, Afghanistan, as the Deputy Commander of the HQ Support Group. During her deployment, she led a support battalion of 400 persons from 40 different countries, looking after the life necessities and security in the NATO Headquarters. During her tour, she completed the rebuilding of an Afghan memorial destroyed by camp construction activity, and led a charity fund raiser for a local orphanage.
 
Her career as a public servant started at Treasury Board Secretariat and Department of Finance. Later, she joined the Department of National Defence, coordinating Army international interoperability programs. Since February 2017 she has joined us as the Manager of Search and Rescue, at the Canadian Coast Guard.

Evan Boettger enrolled in the Canadian Armed Forces as a Reservist in 1976 and served until his retirement from the Royal Canadian Navy in 2015. Evan joined the Public Service at National Defence in 1989 but decided to remain an active Reservist. From 1989 until 2015 Evan balanced parallel military and civilian careers, and since his retirement from the military, is now relieved to have only one career to focus on. 

Evan served in numerous Canadian naval ships, in roles such as a Signalman, Bridge Watch-keeper, Navigation Officer, Deck Officer, Operations Officer, and Executive Officer, in addition to short service in ships of United Kingdom and France.  Evan was honoured to command several ships and units including HMC Ships Fort Steele and Porte St. Louis at sea, HMCS Carleton in Ottawa and Port Security Units in Maritime Forces Atlantic. Evan also served in several overseas missions and special assignments outside the Navy including service in Afghanistan, Kosovo, and South Sudan, as well as in Canadian Special Operations Forces Command. 

At National Defence, Evan worked in major shipbuilding and aerospace projects for the Navy and the Air Force. In 2002, Evan joined the Canadian Coast Guard as the Manager of Project Management in Integrated Technical Services. Evan is currently Project Director for two Incident Command System projects, as well as National Project Manager for the 24/7 Regional Operations Centre and National Command Centre Project.

status_message: Ann Harvey (1811-1860). Born in Isle aux Morts, Newfoundland, the daughter of a fisherman and the eldest of eight children she often spent time helping her father. While fishing in July 1828, they noticed debris floating in the water, and realized that there was a shipwreck nearby. Ann Harvey, her father, twelve year old brother, and the family dog went out in their boat to locate the wreck, and found a large group of survivors on a tiny island. The family managed to save more than 160 people, and the rescue became famous across province. Ann Harvey became known as the Grace Darling of Newfoundland (from an English woman who participated in a similar rescue). http://ow.ly/Kbt630dblWW

In 1997, a team of hydrographers conducted survey work of Allen Bay, aboard CCGS Henry Larsen. They left a time capsule, ashore, beside one of the benchmarks that they used during the survey. It contained a full crew list and a list of the names of the hydrographic team. Byron Briggs, the current Commanding Officer of CCGS Henry Larsen, was part of that 1997 crew list as the Second Officer. The time capsule was later discovered in 2016 by the Bulford family that was hiking in the area. They contacted the Coast Guard shortly after the discovery, to share news of their find. 

In 2017, the Bulfords will complete the last year of deployment in Resolute Bay and wondered if CCGS Henry Larsen was going to be in the area this summer, and if the ship’s crew wanted to see the time capsule before returning it safely to where it was found before winter set in. A crew change in mid-September of 2017 enabled Captain Briggs to return to the ship, in Resolute Bay, in time to welcome all five Bulford family members onboard the icebreaker.  The time capsule was updated with a 2017 ship’s crew list and a list of CHS hydrographers. The Bulfords also included the story of how/when they found it. Who knows when it will be “rediscovered” or by who? 

Photo caption: A photographic keepsake of a great visit aboard CCGS Henry Larsen. Captain Byron Briggs and the Bulford family. In purple, young Lily is seen holding the time capsule she discovered in 2016.
